texts.value: Testis-specific serine/threonine-protein kinase required during spermatid development. Phosphorylates 'Ser-288' of TSKS. Involved in the late stages of spermatogenesis, during the reconstruction of the cytoplasm. During spermatogenesis, required for the transformation of a ring-shaped structure around the base of the flagellum originating from the chromatoid body

Kinase activity is specifically inhibited by 2 classes of compounds: biphenyl compounds (1,1'-(biphenyl-4,4'-diyl)bis(2,2-dihydroxyethanone)) and 1,2,7-trialky-1H-imidazo[4,5-g]quinoxalin-6-one. Activated by phosphorylation on Thr-174 and potentially by autophosphorylation
Interacts with TSSK2. Interacts with HSP90; this interaction stabilizes TSSK1 (By similarity)
In spermatozoa, present in the sperm head and in the flagellum
Testis-specific. Present in sperm (at protein level)
Ubiquitinated; HSP90 activity negatively regulates ubiquitination and degradation
TSSK1B might be used as a target for male contraception or and intra-vaginal spermicides
Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. CAMK Ser/Thr protein kinase family

citation.title: Expression analysis of the human testis-specific serine/threonine kinase (TSSK) homologues. A TSSK member is present in the equatorial segment of human sperm.
Identification of the sucrose non-fermenting related kinase SNRK, as a novel LKB1 substrate.
Molecular cloning and characterization of FKSG81, a novel gene located on human chromosome 5.
Complete sequencing and characterization of 21,243 full-length human cDNAs.
The DNA sequence and comparative analysis of human chromosome 5.
The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).
Validation of a testis specific serine/threonine kinase [TSSK] family and the substrate of TSSK1 & 2, TSKS, as contraceptive targets.
Identification of peptide substrate and small molecule inhibitors of testis-specific serine/threonine kinase1 (TSSK1) by the developed assays.
Expression and localization of five members of the testis-specific serine kinase (Tssk) family in mouse and human sperm and testis.
Patterns of somatic mutation in human cancer genomes.
